Synthesis of chiral salen-MnIII complexes tagged with ionic liquid as recoverable homogeneous catalysts for the oxidative kinetic resolution of (±)-secondary alcohols Pooja Chaudhary Investigation Formal analysis a Christophe Len Writing – review & editing a b Surendra Singh Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, University of Delhi, Delhi 110007, India Department of Chemistry University of Delhi Delhi 110007 India aDepartment of Chemistry, University of Delhi, Delhi 110007, India b Chimie ParisTech, PSL University, CNRS, Institute of Chemistry for Life and Health Sciences, 11 rue Pierre et Marie Curie, F-75231 Paris cedex 05, France Chimie ParisTech, PSL University CNRS, Institute of Chemistry for Life and Health Sciences 11 rue Pierre et Marie Curie, F-75231 Paris cedex 05 France bChimie ParisTech, PSL University, CNRS, Institute of Chemistry for Life and Health Sciences, 11 rue Pierre et Marie Curie, F-75231 Paris cedex 05, France ⁎ Corresponding author. New chiral salen ligands tagged with imidazolium based ionic liquids (ILs) were synthesized from the 5-bromopentyl benzoate functionality at C-5 position of salicylaldehyde moiety, N-methylimidazole, and (1R,2R)-1,2-diphenylethane-1,2-diamine/(1R,2R)-cyclohexane-1,2-diamine in 81–92% yields. The chiral salen ligands were further reacted with Mn(OAc)2.4H2O in dry methanol under N2 atmosphere, followed by air oxidation with LiCl to produce the IL tagged chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a–c) and 2(a–c) in 79-86% yields. The catalytic activities of these complexes were evaluated in the oxidative kinetic resolution of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) with N-bromosuccinimide (NBS) as an oxidizer in biphasic solvent system [H2O - organic solvent (2: 1, v/v)] at 0 °C. The enantioselective oxidation of various (±)-secondary alcohols catalyzed by complex 1c (1 mol%) afforded the chiral secondary alcohols with up to 99% enantiomeric excess and 29.6 k rel (selectivity factor) value. The IL tagged chiral salen-MnIII complex 1c was easily recovered with hexane and subsequently reused for five recycles with no significant loss in conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) and ee of the resolved product. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Enantiopure secondary alcohols are the important compounds, which employed as useful synthetic intermediates in medicinal, fertilizer, and fine chemical industries [1–3]. To achieve highly enantiopure secondary alcohols, the oxidative kinetic resolution (OKR) of (±)-secondary alcohols is one of the most attractive and practical method [4,5]. In the literature, the enantioselective oxidation is well known using enzyme catalysts [6,7]. Recently, various non-enzymatic catalysts were also developed for the enantioselective oxidation of (±)-alcohols. Over the past decades, various chiral ligands with Ru [8,9], Co [10], Ir [11], Fe [12], Pd [4,13–15], and Mn [16–24] metal ions were reported as catalysts in the OKR of (±)-secondary alcohols. Among all, the chiral salen-MnIII complexes are examined as the most efficient catalysts for the OKR of (±)-secondary alcohols due to their easy synthetic procedures and good catalytic activity. In 1997, Noyori and co-workers reported the first route for kinetic resolution of racemic alcohols in the presence of chiral Ru(II)-complexes [25]. Subsequently in 1998, Katsuki and co-workers described the enantioselective oxidation of alcohols using BINOL-derived chiral salen-MnIII complexes as catalysts with iodosylbenzene as a terminal oxidizer [26]. Later, many researchers reported the non-recyclable and recyclable chiral salen-MnIII complexes with excellent enantioselectivity for the OKR of various (±)-secondary alcohols using different oxidizers such as PhI(OAc)2 [16–19,22,27–31], NBS [32,33], NaOCl [23,34], and H2O2 [35]. In recent years, several recoverable homogeneous {dimeric [18], polymeric [19,28], macrocyclic [29,33], IL-bridged [30], PNIPAAm [poly(Nisopropylacrylamide)]-functionalized [31]} and heterogeneous {resin supported sulfonato [36], IL-modified mesoporous silica supported [20,21], and mesoporous helical silica supported [37]} chiral salen-MnIII complexes were reported for the OKR of various (±)-secondary alcohols. The heterogeneous catalysts provide easy handling of the catalysts, and allow the easy separation of product from the catalyst. Despite all these advantages, few heterogeneous catalysts encounter the problems such as decrease in activity of catalysts, high cost of catalysts, and leaching of the catalysts. Although homogeneous catalysis produced chiral secondary alcohols with high enantioselectivity but it also has few drawbacks like difficulty in isolating the catalyst from the product or the lack of catalyst recyclability. The recoverability of the homogeneous catalyst from the catalytic system make the process in demand for the OKR of (±)-secondary alcohols. In the literature, the excellent catalytic efficiency and recoverability reported for ionic liquid (IL) attached chiral salen-MnIII complexes in the enantioselective epoxidation of styrene [38,39] and the OKR of (±)-secondary alcohols [30]. Li et al. described that the accumulation of 1-propylamine-3-methylimidazolium bromide at the C-5, 5′ positions of the salicylaldehyde moiety of Jacobsen complex reduces its enantioselectivity for the OKR of (±)-secondary alcohols because of the less steric hindrance shown by -CH2-IL group as compared to bulky tert-butyl group [30]. To overcome this issue, we designed chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a–c) and 2(a–c) tagged with imidazolium ionic liquids to achieve excellent enantioselectivity in the OKR of (±)-secondary alcohols (Fig. 1 ). We introduced the 5-bromopentylbenzoate group at C-5 position of salicylaldehyde moiety of the Jacobsen salen ligand and then attached to N-methylimidazole to obtain N-methylimidazolium IL tagged salen ligands and their MnIII complexes 1(a–c) and 2(a–c). These synthesized complexes were evaluated as catalysts in the OKR of (±)-secondary alcohols with NBS (oxidizer) in biphasic solvent system at 0 °C. 2 Results and Discussion New chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a–c) and 2(a–c) tagged with imidazolium ILs were synthesized according to Scheme 1. 3′-(tert-Butyl)-5′-formyl-4′-hydroxy-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-carboxylic acid (3) was synthesized by following the previously reported procedure [40]. The esterification of 3′-(tert-butyl)-5′-formyl-4′-hydroxy-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-carboxylic acid (3) with 5-bromopentan-1-ol using DCC and DMAP afforded the bromoester 4 in 80% yield [40]. The bromide [Br] ̄ anion containing IL 5a was synthesized by the treatment of bromoester 4 with N-methylimidazole [41]. The tetrafluoroborate [BF4] ̄ and hexafluorophosphate [PF6] ̄ anion containing ILs 5b and 5c were synthesized by anion exchange of IL 5a using KBF4 and KPF6, respectively in distilled water [41] and confirmed by 1H-, 19F-, and 31P-NMR spectroscopy. The characteristic N-CH-N proton peak of imidazolium cation in the compounds 5b and 5c (having [BF4] ̄ and [PF6] ̄ anions, respectively), show the upfield shift from the [Br] ̄ anion containing IL 5a (δ = 9.19 to 9.11 ppm in 5b and δ = 9.19 to 9.07 ppm in 5c) (Fig. 2 ). The presence of [BF4] ̄ and [PF6] ̄ anions in ILs 5b and 5c were also identified by the 19F-NMR spectroscopy, where the spectral peaks observed at δ = -148.31 ppm and δ = -70.48 ppm (d, J P-F = 710.6 Hz) for compound 5b and 5c, respectively (ESI). The 31P-NMR spectrum of IL 5c shows spectral peak at δ = -144.04 ppm (septet, J P-F = 711.2 Hz) also confirms the presence of [PF6] ̄ anion in IL 5c (ESI). Chiral salen ligands 6(a–c) and 7(a–c), tagged with imidazolium ILs were produced by the condensation of different anion containing ILs 5(a–c) with (1R,2R)-1,2-diphenylethane-1,2-diamine and (1R,2R)-cyclohexane-1,2-diamine, respectively in 81–92% yields [40]. The obtained chiral salen ligands 6(a–c) and 7(a–c) were characterized by HRMS, CHN analysis, 1H-, 19F-, 31P-, 13C-, DEPT-135, HSQC NMR spectroscopic experiments, UV-vis, and FT-IR spectroscopy (ESI). In 1H-NMR spectra of chiral salen ligands 6(a-c) and 7(a-c), the characteristic azomethine (CH=N) proton signal appeared at 8.6 and 8.7 ppm and in FT-IR spectra, the stretching frequencies for azomethine (CH=N) bond appeared at around 1625–1631 cm−1, which indicate the successful synthesis of chiral salen ligands 6(a–c) and 7(a–c). The chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c) were obtained in 79-86% yields by treating the chiral salen ligands 6(a-c) and 7(a-c) with Mn(OAc)2.4H2O in dry methanol under a N2 atmosphere, followed by reaction with LiCl in open air [40], and characterized by TGA, HRMS, CHN analysis, UV-vis, and FT-IR spectroscopy (ESI). The synthesized chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c) tagged with imidazolium ILs displayed characteristic bands at around 1600-1601 cm−1 for azomethine bond, which observed at lower wavenumber from their corresponding chiral salen ligands 6(a-c) and 7(a-c) due to coordinate bond formation between azomethine (CH=N) nitrogen atom and Mn ion [42]. The successful synthesis of complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c) also confirmed by the presence of new characteristic peaks at around 1538–1540 cm−1 (C-O) and 574–577 cm−1 (Mn-O) in FT-IR spectra [39,43]. Moreover, the IL tagged chiral salen ligands and their MnIII complexes showed additional peaks at 3408-3411 cm−1 and 622–624 cm−1, which were attributed to the characteristic peak of imidazole moiety [38]. These explanations indicate that IL moiety has been effectively tagged with chiral salen-MnIII complexes. The absorption peaks appeared at around 265 and 304 nm in the UV-vis spectra of IL tagged chiral salen ligands 6(a-c) and 7(a-c) assigned to the π-π* transitions in ligands. The absorption peaks observed at around 304 nm slightly red shifted to 310 nm in the UV-vis spectra of IL tagged chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c). The new absorption peaks appeared at around 436 nm was assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition (Fig. 3 A and 3B) [39,43]. TGA thermograms of chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c) shows that all the complexes are thermally stable up to 300 °C and after that the degradation of complexes started. The decomposition of organic parts completed up to 600 °C (Fig. 4 ) [44]. Elemental analysis (C, H, and N) for IL tagged chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c) was found to be coherence with the theoretical value of C, H, and N. The optimization of reaction conditions was carried out with (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) as an ideal substrate in the OKR reaction. Initially, the enantioselective oxidation of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) was performed in the absence of catalyst and no enantioselectivity was observed, which approves the inevitability of chiral salen-MnIII complex in the OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) (Table 1 , entry 1). The OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) using 1.5 mol% of IL tagged salen-MnIII complex 1c as a catalyst in the presence of 0.7 equiv. of NBS and 0.8 equiv. of KOAc was carried out in biphasic solvent system as reported by Maity et al. [33] but high conversion (78%) was achieved for (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a), which is not favorable for the OKR reaction (Table 1, entry 2). The decrease in catalyst loading to 1 mol% lowered the conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) to 72% with retention of ee (97%) of (R)-phenylethanol (8a) (Table 1, entry 3). The amount of NBS (oxidizer) was also varied in the range of 0.7 equiv. to 0.4 equiv. to optimize the conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a). The 0.6 equiv. of NBS was found to be an optimum amount to achieved 62% conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) and 92% ee of (R)-1-phenylethanol (8a) after 2 h (Table 1, entries 3-7). Further, the effects of temperature were studied on the enantioselective oxidation of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a). The reaction temperature was varied in the range of 20 °C to 0 °C and best results (62% conv., 96% ee) obtained at 0 °C, which signifies that on decreasing the reaction temperature from 20 °C to 0 °C, the increase in enantioselectivity was observed (Table 1, entries 4, 8, and 9). The reaction was also performed by varying the catalyst 1c loading from 1 mol% under these optimized reaction conditions. At lower catalyst loading (0.5 mol%), the decrease in conversion (49%) and enantioselectivity (78% ee) was attained for the OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) (Table 1, entry 10) whereas at higher catalyst loading (1.5-2.0 mol%), the conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) was slightly increased to give almost comparable ee's (97% ee) of (R)-1-phenylethanol (8a) (Table 1, entries 11 and 12). Thus, 1 mol% of the catalyst loading designated as an optimum amount to achieved a good enantioselectivity in the OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a). From the above results, it can be concluded that the enantioslectivity and conversion of reaction is strongly connected with the catalyst loading, NBS loading, and reaction temperature [23]. In the chiral salen-MnIII complex catalyzed OKR of secondary alcohols, typically KOAc as an additive is required [32,45]. We also studied the effects of different equivalents of KOAc on the enantioselectivity of the OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a). When the equivalent of KOAc decreases, the ee of (R)-1-phenylethanol (8a) also decreases. It shows that the enantioselectivity of reaction is associated with the amounts of KOAc because KOAc neutralize the HBr produced during the oxidation of secondary alcohols [45]. Hence, the 0.8 equiv. of KOAc was found to be the optimum amount to achieve excellent ee of (R)-1-phenylethanol (8a) (Table 1, entries 9, 13 and 14). In the OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a), the catalyst 1c selectively oxidize the (S)-1-phenylethanol (8a) to acetophenone 9a and leaving behind unreacted 1-phenylethanol (8a) enriched with (R)-configuration. Solvents are typically a key factor in the OKR of secondary alcohols. Effect of different solvents were investigated using salen-MnIII complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c) as catalysts for the OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) and the results are summarized in Table 2 . When H2O as a solvent was used 26-37% conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) was achieved with catalysts 1(a-c) and 2(a-c), but an observable difference in enantiomeric excess of chiral 1-phenylethanol was observed for hydrophilic {[Br] ̄ and [BF4] ̄} and hydrophobic [PF6] ̄ anions containing salen-MnIII complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c) (Table 2, entries 1-6). In case of hydrophilic {[Br] ̄ and [BF4] ̄} anions bearing complexes 1(a-b) and 2(a-b), some extent of enantioselectivity was observed, possibly because the complexes 1(a-b) and 2(a-b) are soluble in H2O (Table 2, entries 1-4 & Fig. 5 ). But in case of hydrophobic [PF6] ̄ anion bearing complexes 1c and 2c, negligible enantioselectivity was obtained due to the insolubility of the complexes in H2O (Table 2, entries 5 and 6 & Fig. 5). Using catalyst 1c, the OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) was also checked in sole CH2Cl2 and poor ee (5%) and k rel was observed, which could be explained by the fact that KOAc is insoluble in CH2Cl2 (Table 2, entry 7). Non-polar solvents like hexane and toluene when mixed with H2O, poor conversion and ee was observed, this may be due to the insolubility of catalyst 1c in the non-polar solvents (Table 2, entries 8 and 9). In case of moderately polar solvents (CH2Cl2, C2H4Cl2, CHCl3) mixed with H2O, the conversion of the (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) was obtained in 53-62% with 76-96% ee's and mixture of H2O and CH2Cl2 was found to be the optimum solvent combination to achieved the 96% ee after 2 h (Table 2, entries 10-12). The polar aprotic solvents like MeCN, 1,4-dioxane, acetone, EtOAc, DMF, and THF mixed with H2O gave less ee's and k rel values (Table 2, entries 13–18). Polar protic solvent like t BuOH mixed with H2O also gave poor ee of (R)-1-phenylethanol (8a) and low k rel value (Table 2, entry 19). Different chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c) tagged with ILs were screened in the OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) at 0 °C. The chiral complexes 1c and 2c containing hydrophobic [PF6] ̄ anions exhibited good enantioselectivity of (R)-1-phenylethanol (8a) with better k rel value as compared to complexes 1(a-b) and 2(a-b), having hydrophilic [Br] ̄ and [BF4] ̄ anions (Table 3 , entries 1-6). This may be due to the more solubility of complex 1c and 2c in CH2Cl2 as compared to other complexes containing hydrophilic [Br] ̄ and [BF4] ̄ anions (Fig. 6 ). The catalyst 2(a-b) showed significantly low conversion in OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) compared to the catalysts 1(a-b), due to more hydrophobicity of the (1R,2R)-1,2-diphenylethane-1,2-diamine than (1R,2R)-cyclohexane-1,2-diamine (Fig. 7 A). It was also observed that the conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) and ee of (R)-1-phenylethanol (8a) were steady after 2 h of reaction (Fig. 7 A and B). The catalytic activity of complex 1c in OKR of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) is comparable to Jacobsen catalyst but has an extra advantage of easy recoverability of complex (Table 3, entries 3 and 7). After optimizing the reaction conditions, the catalytic activities of the IL tagged chiral salen-MnIII complex 1c was explored for (±)-ortho-, meta-, and para-substituted 1-phenylethanols and several other (±)-secondary alcohols (Table 4 ). The enantioselective oxidation of (±)-para-substituted 1-phenylethanols showed the excellent enantioselectivities and high k rel values except for electron-donating substituted 1-phenylethanols (Table 4, entries 2, 4, 6, 11-13). In the OKR of (±)-para-halosubstituted 1-phenylethanols, the ee's of (R)-para-halosubstituted 1-phenylethanols was found to be in the order of Br > Cl > F. The enantioselective oxidation of (±)-1-(4-nitrophenyl)ethanol (8k) show better ee and k rel (15.6) values than the electron-donating group (-OMe and -Me) containing 1-phenylethanols (±)-8l and (±)-8m. The OKR of (±)-ortho-substituted 1-phenylethanols ((±)-8e, (±)-8g and (±)-8i) proceeded with very low enantioselectivities except for (±)-1-(2-fluorophenyl)ethanol (8c) and (±)-1-(o-tolyl)ethanol (8n) (Table 4, entries 3, 5, 7, 9, and 14). It is evident from the results that (±)-ortho-substituted 1-phenylethanols show the steric hindrance due to the substituents presents around the hydroxyl group and plays a crucial role in the complete effectiveness of the OKR reaction. The bromo- and nitro-substituents at meta-position of (±)-1-phenylethanols were also tested and high enantioselectivities and k rel values were obtained as compared to the corresponding (±)-ortho- and para-susbtituted 1-phenylethanols (Table 4, entries 8 and 10). The influence of steric hindrance on the OKR reaction was also confirmed by using (±)-1-(naphthalen-2-yl)ethanol (8o) and (±)-1-(naphthalen-1-yl)ethanol (8p) as substrates and the enantioselective oxidation of (±)-8o afforded the (R)-8o with 96% ee and 12.1 k rel value whereas (±)-8p resolved with poor enantioselectivity and very low k rel value (Table 4, entries 15 and 16). (±)-1,2,3,4-Tetrahydronaphthalenol (8q) resolved with moderate enantioselectivity after 2.5 h (Table 4, entry 17). Heteroatom (nitrogen) containing (±)-1-(pyridin-2-yl)ethanol (8r) was also tested in the OKR reaction and no oxidation was occurred even after 3 h (Table 4, entry 18). These results signify that, the enantioselectivity of reaction is strongly affected by the electronic interactions between the catalyst 1c and the substrate. The meta-, and para-substituted 1-phenylethanols gave excellent enantioselectivity values due to favorable electronic interaction between catalyst 1c and the substrate. Whereas in case of (±)-ortho-substituted 1-phenylethanols, the presence of bulky substituents at the ortho-position of 1-phenylethanols hindered the interaction with catalyst 1c, which provides enantiopure 1-phenylethanol with less enantiomeric excess. As the size of the substituent attached to ortho-position of 1-phenylethanols increases, the enantioselective oxidation of 1-phenylethanols decreases. The mechanistic pathway for the OKR of (±)-secondary alcohols is already well explained by Corey's and Zhao's group [23,45]. We compared the results of literature reported homogeneous chiral salen-MnIII complexes with IL tagged chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1c and 2c for the oxidative kinetic resolution of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a). It was observed that most of the complexes required comparable or high catalyst loading, with the exception of polymeric salen-MnIII complex (ESI, Table 1, entry 3), to achieve enantiopure 1-phenylethanol in 55.3-99.3% ee's. Enantioselectivity obtained with literature reported complexes is less or comparable to complexes 1c and 2c (up to 96% ee), with few exceptions such as dimeric salen-MnIII complex (ESI, Table 1, entry 5), IL-bridged dimeric salen-MnIII complex (ESI, Table 1, entry 7), and macrocyclic salen-MnIII complex (ESI, Table 1, entry 10), which provided the enantiopure 1-phenylethanol in 99% ee. The recoverability and reusability of the catalyst is very important for an effective catalytic system. The recovery of chiral catalyst 1c was checked in the enantioselective oxidation of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) with NBS (oxidizer) in biphasic solvent system [H2O:CH2Cl2 (2:1)] at 0 °C and results are summarized in Table 5 . After achieving an optimum conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) and ee of the (R)-1-phenylethanol (8a), two layers (organic and aqueous) of reaction mixture were segregated and the collected organic layer was washed with distilled water to remove KOAc and NBS from the organic phase. The organic phase was then washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure then hexane was added to it. The catalyst 1c was precipitated out and collected after centrifugation (ESI, Fig. 1). The recovered catalyst 1c was reused for five recycles with no significant loss in conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) and ee of the resolved product. The slight decrease in activity of the catalyst was observed due to the physical loss of catalyst 1c during work-up. The selective solubility of complexes 1(a-c) and 2(a-c) in CH2Cl2 plays a key role in the recoverability of the complexes from the reaction mixture. Complexes 1c and 2c are more soluble in CH2Cl2 and easily extracted from the reaction mixture with CH2Cl2, whereas complexes 1(a-b) and 2(a-b) cannot be extracted from the reaction mixture because of their more solubility in water as compared to CH2Cl2 (Figs. 5 and 6). The structural properties of the catalyst after its reusability were studied by using FT-IR, UV-vis spectroscopy and TGA analysis (ESI, Figs. 2-4). The FT-IR spectrum of recovered catalyst 1c was recorded after second and fifth recycle and no major changes were observed in the spectra. Additionally, the UV-vis and TGA spectra were recorded for reused catalyst 1c and compared with fresh catalyst and the data are in agreement with the fresh catalyst, these results indicate that the catalyst structure is retain during the reaction. 3 Conclusion Novel chiral salen-MnIII complexes tagged with imidazolium based ILs were synthesized in 79-86% yields and investigated as catalysts for the oxidative kinetic resolution of (±)-secondary alcohols with NBS as an oxidizer in biphasic solvent system [H2O:CH2Cl2 (2:1)]. Excellent enantioselectivities were achieved at 0 °C for the oxidative kinetic resolution of (±)-meta- and para-substituted 1-phenylethanols except (±)-ortho-substituted 1-phenylethanols by using 1 mol% of complex 1c as a catalyst. The IL tagged chiral salen-MnIII complex 1c easily recovered with hexane and reused for five recycles with no significant loss in conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) and ee of the resolved product. coredata.dc:description: New chiral salen ligands tagged with imidazolium based ionic liquids (ILs) were synthesized from the 5-bromopentyl benzoate functionality at C-5 position of salicylaldehyde moiety, N-methylimidazole, and (1R,2R)-1,2-diphenylethane-1,2-diamine/(1R,2R)-cyclohexane-1,2-diamine in 81–92% yields. The chiral salen ligands were further reacted with Mn(OAc)2.4H2O in dry methanol under N2 atmosphere, followed by air oxidation with LiCl to produce the IL tagged chiral salen-MnIII complexes 1(a–c) and 2(a–c) in 79-86% yields. The catalytic activities of these complexes were evaluated in the oxidative kinetic resolution of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) with N-bromosuccinimide (NBS) as an oxidizer in biphasic solvent system [H2O - organic solvent (2: 1, v/v)] at 0 °C. The enantioselective oxidation of various (±)-secondary alcohols catalyzed by complex 1c (1 mol%) afforded the chiral secondary alcohols with up to 99% enantiomeric excess and 29.6 k rel (selectivity factor) value. The IL tagged chiral salen-MnIII complex 1c was easily recovered with hexane and subsequently reused for five recycles with no significant loss in conversion of (±)-1-phenylethanol (8a) and ee of the resolved product.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of chiral salen-MnIII complexes tagged with ionic liquid as recoverable homogeneous catalysts for the oxidative kinetic resolution of (±)-secondary alcohols
